item.title:
“I will stay with these people until the end.”
The Economist’s editor-in-chief, @zannymb, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky https://t.co/VHu5GLP9Oy
Before the Taliban seized power last year, almost 30% of civil servants were women. Now women have been purged from most workplaces https://t.co/DIxKsUq39P

Russia claimed its attack on Kyiv was designed to distract Ukrainian forces from the real action in Donbas. Yet evidence shows that Russia intended to take Kyiv and expected to do so quickly https://t.co/EtY3iFF5DT
“We believe in victory,” Volodymyr Zelensky told The Economist in a face-to-face interview in Kyiv last week https://t.co/oU8NdlxBNj

On March 25th @zannymb, editor-in-chief of The Economist, travelled to Kyiv to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
Here is the inside story of how she and @ArkadyOstrovsky, The Economist’s Russia editor, made it into the Ukrainian president’s war room https://t.co/QmH2g4kZac
New numbers, shared with The Economist, suggest that the conflict in Ukraine has created the largest flow of refugees in a single year since at least 1990 https://t.co/RoYXw68e95

The Economist’s editor-in-chief, Zanny Minton Beddoes, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
In a wide-ranging interview, the Ukrainian president discussed the state of the war and why Putin must be defeated https://t.co/T3dD5jhAMp
Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has shown Europe that it needs a new China policy https://t.co/Sm5oXMrYaj
If the gas keeps flowing, so will the debate about the morality of buying it https://t.co/bFpBezdEQE
Macaroni cheese is now an American staple. But it probably arrived there via France – and Thomas Jefferson https://t.co/5i056D1xvd
KAL’s cartoon https://t.co/rd5oSKf73M
Ukraine has won the first phase of the war simply by surviving. Now it needs to advance, and so Volodymyr Zelensky needs redoubled Western help https://t.co/ZeyamMgvpV

EU leaders hope to send a message to China’s leader, Xi Jinping, that the Ukraine war is a defining moment for relations, and for China’s image if it refuses to use its influence to end the bloodshed https://t.co/0ZiEtkKR2K
It seems that Russia is keen to use humanitarian gestures in Ukraine to the same effect as in Syria https://t.co/rpvYjM5pDB

“We believe in victory. It’s impossible to believe in anything else.” Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, speaks to The Economist’s editor-in-chief @zannymb and Russia editor @arkadyostrovsky, on a special episode of “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/glOHf65qrU
Hungary is still a democracy, but a damaged one. Its election on April 3rd will be seen as a global struggle between liberal democracy and populist autocracy https://t.co/f1Fbys9zYP
Ordering coffins, comforting the bereaved and fixing potholes https://t.co/MeCwFVQou2
Chinese leaders want the mood to be “business as usual”. But the summit between China and the European Union will be anything but normal https://t.co/L1Ah4IGSXf
Florida has overtaken New York to become America’s third-most-populous state. Its economic and political heft is growing, too https://t.co/MemSCfGrmZ
You have to go back 80 years to find a remotely comparable attrition of senior officers with that Russia is experiencing today https://t.co/UqtMR7kedE
Yale School of Management professor Jeffrey Sonnenfeld believes Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will mark a shift in support for globalisation. He tells our columnist why https://t.co/TUkam8sRSj
During three centuries of imperialism, Russia has repeatedly been at war in Europe. A strong, democratic Ukraine would thwart its expansionism https://t.co/dyvzr5sKZy
Russian officials have employed various tactics to defend the value of the currency https://t.co/emBg0gETbm

On March 25th @zannymb, editor-in-chief of The Economist, travelled to Kyiv to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
Here is the inside story of how she and @ArkadyOstrovsky, The Economist’s Russia editor, made it into the Ukrainian president’s war room https://t.co/s3h8NBCwQA

On March 25th Zanny Minton Beddoes, editor-in-chief of The Economist, travelled to Kyiv to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
Here is the inside story of how she and Arkady Ostrovsky, The Economist’s Russia editor, made it into the Ukrainian president’s war room https://t.co/m9MY8ISi4T

World leaders are “trying to treat the symptoms instead of curing the disease of dictatorship,” warns Belarus’s opposition leader. “This war is not just between Russia and Ukraine. It is a battle between autocracy and democracy” https://t.co/XvJRSDotzw
Not only could a victory for Ukraine against Russia invigorate the cause of democracy, but it would also enhance European security https://t.co/GwF6kBYSwG

China won't endorse Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, but it won’t condemn it either. Whose side is China really on, and what does its stance mean for global order?
The Economist’s Beijing bureau chief, David Rennie, explains https://t.co/46hoXKuCD0

A decisive victory for Ukraine would deter yet another Russian invasion. The more convincingly Ukraine can see off the Russian army, the more able it will be to resist the compromises that could poison the peace https://t.co/ZyfIHye8px

Whether Vladimir Putin succeeds in snuffing out Ukraine will depend not just on Ukrainians’ astonishing courage, but on the West’s continued determination to give it the help that it needs https://t.co/l8PIgwTe9B

A decisive victory for Ukraine could transform the security of Europe. Our latest cover story outlines what President Volodymyr Zelensky told us in the war room https://t.co/0zD6emRUoB https://t.co/DGElb0MAET
Ramzan Kadyrov’s men appear to have fared no better than the rest of the Russian forces https://t.co/yM8PLCuWAi

Vladimir Putin is a “thug”, says Mikhail Khodorkovsky, a former oil mogul and political prisoner. The West must face him down now or prepare for something worse, he warns in a guest essay for The Economist https://t.co/ufuzIqkzfa

“It's not about being brave or not,” the president says. “I have to act the way I do...you have to be honest, so that people believe you. You don’t need to try. You need to be yourself” https://t.co/aZGlSyPAal
Even if Joe Biden shows skill and sound judgment in the new cold war, he, like Harry Truman, may not get much credit for it until decades later https://t.co/Qw7bR7KILN

“If the West wants to save its zone of peace and prosperity it must welcome Ukraine in and keep Russia out.” Russia’s former foreign minister argues that Putin’s regime is too dangerous to carry on business with when the war ends https://t.co/6CRQKOq6dM

China won't endorse Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, but it won’t condemn it either. Whose side is China really on, and what does its stance mean for global order?
The Economist’s Beijing bureau chief, David Rennie, explains https://t.co/N7BBjuUmSH

Vladimir Putin “props up” Alexander Lukashenko’s regime, says @Tsihanouskaya. “The West’s weakness has led to Belarus becoming an accomplice in the most brutal European conflict since the second world war” https://t.co/Vx0qS3XQPF
Russia is pivoting largely because the first phase of its war has been a failure https://t.co/Ya3fw1D6p5

We’re hiring interns to cover foreign affairs. If you have a boundless curiosity about the world and can write about it concisely, wittily and with analytical rigour, we’d like to hear from you https://t.co/JkK5978xln
Countries are rushing to add military capacity https://t.co/tMMqOzYxLu

"The fate of both Belarus & Ukraine is at stake. Belarus can't be free without a free Ukraine & vice versa. Dismantling Lukashenka's dictatorship would help 🇺🇦 win the war". Read my latest article on the crisis in the region at @TheEconomist. https://t.co/Lu0pSZrjh0
The idea that Russia was only ever interested in Donbas is nonsense https://t.co/1mwTCyqHj6
The invasion of Ukraine looks like a turning-point in the fortunes of far-right groups https://t.co/Wa7OohaQis

Whether Vladimir Putin succeeds in snuffing out Ukraine will depend not just on Ukrainians’ astonishing courage, but on the West’s continued determination to give it the help that it needs https://t.co/Ys9kNdJG6j

Andrei Kozyrev believes the prospect of a westernising, democratic and prosperous Ukraine is the nightmare of the Putin regime. “It will be a powerful motivation for Russians to follow suit,” the former Russian foreign minister writes https://t.co/YMlRiwqb1s
“What does a Ukrainian victory look like?” we asked Volodymyr Zelensky. “Victory is being able to save as many lives as possible,” he said https://t.co/XJ6oNtwqnQ
Ukrainian defenders have been sharing known military frequencies, recording Russian communications and uploading them for volunteers to parse for information https://t.co/4nmRStQBUA
“Ukraine needs to stand and survive,” says Volodymyr Zelensky’s chief of staff in an interview with The Economist. “If it doesn’t, Putin will never stop” https://t.co/OLMQjF2sAm
Radios may be less lethal than weapons, but Russia’s failure to invest in communications is hobbling its forces https://t.co/pryDSmqxgY
